Award.AwardTitle: Investigating STEM Literacies in Maker Spaces

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Many communities across the country are developing "maker spaces," environments that combine physical fabrication equipment, social communities of people working together, and educational activities for learning how to design and create works. Increasingly, maker spaces and maker technologies provide extended learning opportunities for school-aged young people. In such environments participants engage in many forms of communication where individuals and groups of people are focused on different projects simultaneously. The research conducted in this project will address an important need of those engaged in the making movement: evidence leading to a better understanding of how participants in maker spaces engage with science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) as they create and produce physical products of personal and social value. Specifically, this research will generate new knowledge regarding how participants: pose and solve problems; identify, organize and integrate information from different sources; integrate information of different kinds (visual, quantitative, and verbal); and share ideas, knowledge and work with others.

To understand and support STEM literacies involved in making, the investigators will study a number of different informal learning sites that self-identify as maker spaces and serve different-aged participants. The project will use ethnographic and design research techniques in three cycles of qualitative research. In Cycle One, the researchers will investigate two adult-oriented maker spaces in order to generate case studies and develop theories about how more experienced adult makers use the spaces and to create case studies of adult maker spaces, and to develop methodological techniques for understanding literacy in maker spaces. In Cycle Two, the study will expand into two out-of-school time youth-oriented maker spaces, building two new case studies and initiating design-based research activities. In Cycle Three, the team will further apply their developing theories and findings, through rapid iterative design-based research, to interventions that support participants' science literacy and making practices in two maker spaces that exist in schools. Through peer-reviewed publications, briefs, conference presentations, presence on websites of local and national maker organizations, project findings will be widely shared with organizations and individuals that are engaged in broadening the base of U.S. science and mathematics professionals for an innovation economy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Making is a potentially rich activity for learning in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). It is popular both in informal learning spaces such as community centers, libraries, museums, and after school centers, and in more formal spaces like schools. Literacies are the ways in which people use representations in social settings to accomplish goals. Literacies are crucial to being successful in making and they help provide a bridge to more formal academic requirements of subject area learning in schools. In this project, we sought to understand how makers across different contexts, different levels of ability, experience, interests, forms of making, ages, and genders engaged in literacies related to STEM fields as they were making.

Investigating STEM Literacies in Makerspaces produced case studies on five makerspaces including a) a 400 member-run space for adults, b) a startup small batch manufacturing and rapid prototyping company, c) a community run fab lab and teen employment program, d) a community center serving 6-11 year olds, and e) an urban public high school. The project produced a framework for understanding and supporting literacy practices across making spaces. These include the ways in which people:

  • Identify, organize, and integrate information across sources (e.g., people, Internet sites)

  • Create and traverse representations to brainstorm, design, and manufacture objects (e.g., sketches to more formal diagrams)

  • Communicate with others for help and feedback

  • Share completed or works-in-progress online in various venues (e.g., blogs, crowdfunding campaigns, how-tos)

  • Document work in an ongoing way for future self-reference or to help others

The framework and the case studies were turned into several publications, and a book, STEM Literacies in Makerspaces: Implications for Learning, Teaching, and Research (Tucker-Raymond & Gravel, In Press). The project also designed a new high school class, Creative Design and Engineering. Among other supports, as part of the class, the project designed scaffolds for: a) tapping into and growing learners’ personal networks in a way that emulates what successful makers do, and b) scaffolds for genres of sharing (blogs, crowdsourcing, “how to” guides). The project also designed two different forms of professional development for teachers: a set of workshops and a semester-long study group. Principles for educator professional learning were identified as part of those efforts and included changing educators’ relationships to disciplines, tools, and learners.
